paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

standardization_needed.parameter: Total K extracted by boiling HNO3 (Table 5)
standardization_needed.reasoning: The table title specifies 'mg K/kg' for both non-exchangeable K and total K (HNO3), and the numerical values are consistent with soil concentrations (mg/kg) rather than per hectare values. This appears to be a typographical error in the table's column header for '100% HNO3 K'.

missing_statistics: Standard errors or confidence intervals for most mean values (e.g., soil K contents, yields) are not provided in the original text, only means and statistical significance (e.g., 'significant differences').

missing_data_identified: Specific values for non-exchangeable K and total HNO3-extractable K for each treatment and site from Table 5 were not fully captured, only the overall averages.
Specific values for Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc K content for each treatment and site (from Figures 1 and 2) were not numerically extracted, only overall averages.

incomplete_descriptions: The specific statistical software used for ANOVA was not initially captured.

insufficient_detail: Detailed N application rates for potatoes across all treatments were not fully specified in the initial extraction.

uncertainty_omissions: Lack of explicit standard deviations or confidence intervals for most reported mean values.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Added specific non-exchangeable K and total HNO3-extractable K values for each treatment and site from Table 5.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Provides more granular quantitative findings, allowing for detailed analysis of treatment effects on K fractions.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Added new primary measurement entries for 'Non-exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (2017)' and 'Total K extracted by boiling HNO3 (2017)' with treatment-specific values.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Added the specific statistical software used for analysis.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Enhances reproducibility and clarity of the statistical approach.
medium_priority_improvements.implementation: Added 'Statistica programme (StatSoft Inc. 2015, Tulsa, USA)' to `analysis_methods`.

medium_priority_improvements.description: Enhanced the description of N application rates for potatoes across different treatments.
medium_priority_improvements.benefit: Provides a more complete picture of the fertilization management practices.

data_enrichment_opportunities.potential_value: Extracting precise numerical values for Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc K content for each treatment and site in 2017.
data_enrichment_opportunities.extraction_approach: Requires image processing/OCR or manual estimation from bar charts, which is beyond standard text extraction capabilities and prone to error without numerical labels.

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium balance and related changes in soil K fractions (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable) under different long-term fertilization treatments in two distinct soil-climatic conditions.

research_methodology.experimental_design: Long-term stationary field experiments (21 years) with 6 fertilization treatments and a fixed crop rotation (potatoes-winter wheat-spring barley), with all three crops grown each year. Soil samples were taken at the beginning and end of the 21-year period, and plant yields were collected annually.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Annual crop harvest; soil samples collected at the start (1996) and end (2017) of the experiment.
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Fertilizer applications in autumn (organic, P, K) and spring (mineral N).
monitoring_timeline: 1996-2017: Annual crop harvest and yield data collection

site_characteristics: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol on loess, Clay loam texture, 265 m a.s.l., Mean annual temperature 8.2 °C, Mean annual precipitation 573 mm, pH CaCl2 5.9, CEC 116 mmol+/kg, Corg 1.06%
Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss, Sandy loam texture, 525 m a.s.l., Mean annual temperature 7.0 °C, Mean annual precipitation 665 mm, pH CaCl2 5.1, CEC 90 mmol+/kg, Corg 1.38%
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: The crop rotation corresponds well with intensive farming systems used in the Czech Republic.

sample_design.replication_levels: Four replications for soil samples (0–30 cm depth); experimental plots are implied to be replicated for each treatment at each site, though not explicitly stated.
sample_design.randomization_approach: Not explicitly stated, but implied by 'trials' and statistical analysis (ANOVA).
controls_and_treatments: FYM 1/2: Half dose of farmyard manure + nitrogen (N) in mineral nitrogen fertilizers
N + ST: Straw of spring barley + nitrogen (N) in mineral nitrogen fertilizers
sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly stated, but ANOVA was used to assess significance.

measurement_protocols: Soil sample preparation: Air-dried, ≤ 2 mm, 0–30 cm depth, four replications. Samples taken in autumn 1996 (before experiment) and after plant harvest in 2017 (from plots with spring barley).
Plant sample preparation: Harvested at maturity, dried at 40°C, dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998).
K content in plants: Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AAS).

Bioavailable K in soil: Mehlich 3 extraction (Mehlich 1984). 3.00 g soil extracted with 30 mL solution (0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA), shaken for 5 min.

Bioavailable K in soil: CaCl2/DTPA (CAT) extraction (CSN EN 13651, 2001). 3.00 g soil extracted with 30 mL solution (0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.01 mol/L 0.002 diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA)), shaken for 1 h.
Exchangeable K (Kex) in soil: Ammonium acetate (NH4OAc) extraction (Haby et al. 1990 modified). 3.00 g soil extracted with 30 mL 1 mol/L ammonium acetate solution at pH 7.00, shaken for 2 h.

Non-exchangeable K (Kne) in soil: Boiling 1 mol/L HNO3 extraction (Helmke and Sparks 2000). 2.5 g finely ground soil heated with 25 mL 1 mol/L HNO3 for 10 min after boiling started. Kne determined by subtracting NH4OAc-determined K from the obtained values.
instrumentation: Atomic Adsorption Spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia) for plant K.
Optical Emission Spectrometer with Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia) for soil K extracts.
quality_control: Soil samples analyzed from 1996 (before experiment establishing) and at the end of 7th crop rotation (2017, shortly after plant harvest).

statistical_approach.significance_testing: Significance level P < 0.001 for correlations; 'statistically significant differences' mentioned for treatment effects.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Not explicitly quantified beyond statistical significance (e.g., no standard deviations or confidence intervals provided for means).
statistical_approach.model_validation: Not applicable (no predictive models developed in this study).

primary_measurements.parameter: Potassium balance (inputs minus outputs) over 21 years
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St) and Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St) treatments. Maximum negative balance (–2376 kg K/ha) was recorded at the mineral nitrogen fertilization treatment (N) at Humpolec site.

primary_measurements.parameter: Crop uptake of potassium (total over 21 years)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St) and Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St) treatments. Humpolec K uptake was 348 kg K/ha higher on average across all variants compared to Hněvčeves.

From farmyard manure (Hněvčeves: 26%, Humpolec: 24%) and from mineral fertilizers (NPK) (Hněvčeves: 52%, Humpolec: 27%). Higher K utilization observed at soils with higher sorption capacity and at lower application doses.

primary_measurements.parameter: Potassium content in plough layer (Mehlich 3) - Average 2017
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across all treatments at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively. Hněvčeves average was 31% higher than Humpolec. Treatment-specific values are presented in Figure 1.

primary_measurements.parameter: Exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (NH4OAc) - Average 2017
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across all treatments at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively. Hněvčeves average was 34.6% higher than Humpolec. Treatment-specific values are presented in Figure 2.

primary_measurements.parameter: Saturation of potassium in cation exchange capacity (CEC) - Average 2017
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across all treatments at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively. Values > 3.50% CEC are considered satisfactory for Czech soils.

primary_measurements.parameter: Potassium content in plough layer (CAT extraction) - Average 2017
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across all treatments at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively. CAT extraction yielded significantly lower K values compared to Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods.

primary_measurements.parameter: Non-exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (2017)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Values for each treatment at Hněvčeves (Luvisol) and Humpolec (Cambisol) sites in 2017. Average at Hněvčeves: 850 mg K/kg; Humpolec: 3000 mg K/kg. Changes in non-exchangeable K were recorded only at the Luvisol site (Hněvčeves).

primary_measurements.parameter: Total K extracted by boiling HNO3 (2017)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Values for each treatment at Hněvčeves and Humpolec sites in 2017. Average at Hněvčeves: 1069 mg K/kg; Humpolec: 3167 mg K/kg. These values represent 100% for comparison of extraction methods.

primary_measurements.parameter: Proportion of non-exchangeable K to total HNO3-extractable K
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Luvisol): 80.9%; Humpolec (Cambisol): 95.2%.

primary_measurements.parameter: Changes in potassium content in plough layer (1996-2017) - Mehlich 3
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST) and Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST) treatments. Values represent the change from 1996 to 2017.

primary_measurements.parameter: Changes in potassium content in plough layer (1996-2017) - Kex
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST) and Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST) treatments. Values represent the change from 1996 to 2017.

primary_measurements.parameter: Changes in potassium content in plough layer (1996-2017) - CAT
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST) and Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST) treatments. Values represent the change from 1996 to 2017.
Average yield over 21 years at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively.
Average yield over 21 years at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively.
Average yield over 21 years at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively.
Range of K content in wheat grain across both sites.
Range of K content in barley grain across both sites.
Average K content in wheat straw at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively.
Average K content in barley straw at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively.
Average K content in potato tubers at Hněvčeves and Humpolec, respectively.

statistical_relationships.measurement_context: Strong positive correlation between Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods for K determination in soil.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Significant tendency to decrease at Hněvčeves site (Luvisol) in variants without K fertilization (Control, N, N+St, FYM 1/2). No significant changes observed at Humpolec site (Cambisol).

temporal_patterns.parameter: Potassium content in plough layer (Mehlich 3, Kex, CAT)
temporal_patterns.trend_description: Decreased in all unfertilized variants over 21 years. The highest decrease was observed at the mineral nitrogen fertilization (N) treatment.

comparative_results.practical_significance: Hněvčeves had a 31% higher average K content (Mehlich 3) in the plough layer compared to Humpolec.
Hněvčeves had a 34.6% higher average exchangeable K content (NH4OAc) in the plough layer compared to Humpolec.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Effect of manure application on exchangeable K
groups_compared: Variants without K fertilization (Control, N, N+St)
comparative_results.statistical_significance: Significant increase with manure application; significantly lowest without K fertilization.
comparative_results.practical_significance: Manure application effectively increased exchangeable K content in the soil, while treatments without K fertilization led to significant decreases.

comparative_results.comparison_type: K uptake by plants between sites
comparative_results.practical_significance: Higher K uptake at Humpolec despite lower bioavailable K in soil, possibly due to higher potato yield and more regular precipitation distribution throughout the vegetation period.

Humpolec (Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss) had much higher non-exchangeable K content (approx. 3000 mg K/kg) compared to Hněvčeves (Haplic Luvisol on loess) (approx. 850 mg K/kg), attributed to differences in parent material and clay mineralogy (2:1 clay minerals, mica, vermiculite).

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.
geographic_details.landscape_position: Not specified beyond altitude and soil parent material.

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Not explicitly classified, but described by temperature and precipitation patterns.

precipitation_patterns.seasonality_Humpolec: Regular distribution throughout the vegetation period, positively influencing K uptake.

climate_characteristics.growing_season: Not explicitly stated, but implied by crop rotation and fertilizer timing.

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam (4.4% clay, 77.0% silt, 18.7% sand); Humpolec: Sandy loam (5.8% clay, 43.6% silt, 50.6% sand)
soil_properties.mineralogy: Hněvčeves: on loess; Humpolec: on loess on paragneiss. Non-exchangeable K is primarily bound at boundaries of 2:1 clay minerals, mica, and vermiculite. The clay mineral type is more important than total clay content for non-exchangeable K.

cropping_systems: Potatoes-winter wheat-spring barley rotation (all three crops grown each year)
sustainability_metrics: Changes in soil K content (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable)

growth_stages_studied: Winter wheat: BBCH 21 (first half of N dose), BBCH 31–32 (second half of N dose)

types: Mineral nitrogen fertilizers (calcium ammonium nitrate, 27% N)
Mineral phosphorus fertilizers (triple super phosphate, 21% P)
timing: Organic fertilizers (farmyard manure, straw): Always applied in autumn (October) to potatoes.
Mineral phosphorus and potassium fertilizers: Applied to each crop in autumn.
Mineral nitrogen fertilizers: Applied to potatoes and spring barley in spring prior to crop establishment.
Mineral nitrogen fertilizers for winter wheat: Dose divided into halves, first applied at BBCH 21, second at BBCH 31–32.

input_rates.N_application_rates: Potatoes: 120 kg N/ha (N, NPK, N+St treatments); 165 kg N/ha (total N in organic for FYM 1/2); 330 kg N/ha (total N in organic for FYM 1). Winter wheat: 140 kg N/ha (115 kg N/ha for FYM 1/2). Spring barley: 70 kg N/ha (50 kg N/ha for FYM 1/2).
input_rates.P_application_rates: 30 kg P/ha for NPK treatment (wheat and barley); other treatments' P doses depended on nutrient content in applied organic fertilizers.
input_rates.K_application_rates: 100 kg K/ha for NPK treatment (wheat and barley); other treatments' K doses depended on nutrient content in applied organic fertilizers. Average annual K doses in mineral fertilizers for more than 20 years in CR were only 5–6 kg K/ha agricultural soil.

balance_calculations.potassium_balance_21_years: See primary_measurements for K balance (inputs minus outputs)

data_collection_schedule: Soil sampling in autumn 1996 (before experiment establishing)
Soil sampling after harvest in 2017 (end of 7th crop rotation)
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Annually for yields; twice for soil properties over 21 years.

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Organic and P/K fertilizers applied in autumn; mineral N fertilizers applied in spring.

long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Indicates depletion of K reserves in unfertilized Luvisol soils, highlighting the importance of K fertilization for long-term soil management.

long_term_trends.parameter: Potassium content in plough layer (Mehlich 3, Kex, CAT)
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Highlights the need for K fertilization to maintain soil K levels, especially in unfertilized or N-only fertilized systems, for sustainable soil management in the Czech Republic.

variability_characterization.inter_annual_variability: Yields and K uptake varied annually due to climatic conditions (e.g., precipitation distribution).
variability_characterization.spatial_variability: Significant differences in soil properties, climate, crop yields, K uptake, and K dynamics observed between the two sites (Hněvčeves and Humpolec).
variability_characterization.measurement_uncertainty: Not explicitly quantified beyond statistical significance.
drivers_of_variability: Soil type and parent material (Haplic Luvisol on loess vs. Stagnic Cambisol on loess on paragneiss)
Climatic conditions (mean annual temperature, mean annual precipitation, precipitation distribution)

methodological_strengths: Long-term (21 years) field experiment, providing valuable insights into long-term K dynamics and sustainability.
Two sites with distinct soil and climatic conditions, allowing for robust comparative analysis of K behavior.
Comprehensive analysis of different K fractions (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable) using multiple established extraction methods (Mehlich 3, CaCl2/DTPA, NH4OAc, boiling HNO3).
Inclusion of a wide range of fertilization treatments, including organic (farmyard manure, straw) and mineral sources, alongside an unfertilized control.
Crop rotation reflects intensive farming systems common in the Czech Republic, enhancing practical relevance.
methodological_limitations: Soil samples for K changes were only taken at the beginning (1996) and end (2017) of the 21-year period, limiting detailed temporal trend analysis or identification of intermediate changes within the period.
The study primarily focused on K content in the plough layer (0-30 cm), not accounting for potential K mobilization from deeper subsoil layers, which can be a significant K source for plants.

While non-exchangeable K contributes to plant availability, the study acknowledges that not all non-exchangeable K is equally plant-available or released at the same rate, which is a general complexity in K dynamics.
The agreement between Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc methods might be lower in 'ordinary agricultural soils' compared to the specific long-term field trials studied, as suggested by the authors.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: Good, most required parameters are present and well-detailed, especially after enhancement.

measurement_precision.detection_limits: Not explicitly stated for K measurements.
measurement_precision.analytical_uncertainty: Not explicitly quantified (e.g., standard deviations or confidence intervals for means are not provided in the text, only means and statistical significance).

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Two distinct sites provide some spatial variability, and the study's findings are relevant to agricultural regions with similar soil and climatic conditions in the Czech Republic.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: High, due to the 21-year duration, capturing long-term effects and trends.
representativeness.system_representativeness: The crop rotation and farming systems are stated to be representative of intensive farming practices in the Czech Republic.

uncertainty_sources: Potential for K mobilization from subsoil not accounted for in balance calculations.
Variability in nutrient content of organic fertilizers (FYM, straw) over the long term, although average doses are provided.
The exact number of experimental plots/replications for treatments is not explicitly stated, only 'four replications' for soil samples.
validation_evidence: Comparison of K saturation in CEC with satisfactory levels for Czech soils (Smatanová and Sušil 2018).
Comparison of non-exchangeable K contents with other long-term trials (Blake et al. 1999, Øgaard and Krogstad 2005).

key_methodological_references: Egnér H., Riehm H., Domingo W.R. (1960): Egner-Riehm method for K determination.
Mehlich A. (1984): Mehlich 3 soil test extractant.
Haby V.A., Russelle M.P., Skogley E.O. (1990): Ammonium acetate extraction (modified procedure).
Helmke P.A., Sparks D.L. (2000): Boiling HNO3 extraction.
Mader P., Száková J., Miholová D. (1998): Dry ashing of biological materials.
comparative_studies: Blake L. et al. (1999): Potassium content, uptake, and balance in European long-term field experiments.
Liu E. et al. (2010): Long-term effect of chemical fertilizer, straw, and manure on soil properties.
Srinivasarao Ch. et al. (2014): Potassium release characteristics, balance, and yield sustainability in long-term experiment.
Øgaard A.F., Krogstad T. (2005): Ability of different soil extraction methods to predict potassium release.
Binner I. et al. (2017): Potassium adsorption and release properties of clays in horticultural substrates.
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: The paper discusses the importance of non-exchangeable K for plant uptake, the role of rhizosphere acidification in K release (Hinsinger and Jaillard 1993, Steingrobe and Claasen 2000), and the binding of non-exchangeable K to 2:1 clay minerals (mica and vermiculite) (Brouder 2011).
benchmarking_data: Official assessment of K pool in CR for loamy soils (Smatanová and Sušil 2018).
Comparison of non-exchangeable K contents with Bad Lauchstadt and Rothamsted sites (Blake et al. 1999) and selected soils in Norway (Øgaard and Krogstad 2005).

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in quantitative data, especially regarding K balances, soil K fractions, and crop yields under various long-term fertilization treatments across two distinct sites.
potential_ambiguities: The exact number of experimental plots/replications for treatments is not explicitly stated, only 'four replications' for soil samples.

The units for '100% HNO3 K' in Table 5 are listed as 'mg K/ha' in the original paper, but the table title and numerical values strongly suggest 'mg K/kg' was intended. The extraction assumes 'mg K/kg' for consistency with other soil concentration measurements.
Standard errors or confidence intervals for most mean values are not provided in the text, only statistical significance (e.g., 'significant differences').
extraction_limitations: Inability to extract specific standard deviations or confidence intervals for most quantitative results, as they were not provided in the text.
Inability to precisely extract numerical values from bar charts (Figures 1 and 2) without explicit labels.
recommended_validation_checks: Verify the intended units for the '100% HNO3 K' values in Table 5 with the authors or related publications if possible.

enhancements_added: Detailed treatment-specific values for non-exchangeable K and total HNO3-extractable K from Table 5.
More granular N application rates for potatoes across treatments.
enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: Enhancements were applied to provide a more complete and precise representation of the study's quantitative results and methodological details, directly sourced from the original paper. This improves the utility and scientific rigor of the extracted information.

validation_quality.validator_notes: The original extraction was largely accurate but lacked granularity in certain quantitative data points (e.g., treatment-specific soil K fractions from tables) and some methodological details. The primary ambiguity identified was a likely unit typo in Table 5 of the original paper, which was handled by inferring the correct unit based on context and explicitly flagging it. The enhanced extraction significantly improves the completeness and precision of the data.
recommended_next_steps: Consider adding a note about the initial K content in 1996 for Mehlich 3, Kex, and CAT if available in the text, to complement the 'changes' data.
If possible, obtain numerical data for Figures 1 and 2 to capture treatment-specific final K values for Mehlich 3 and NH4OAc.

results.paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
